case_name: Madhu Wool Spinning Mills v. the respondent company

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1113 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

issues.text: Whether the respondent company is liable to be wound up under section 433(c) of the Companies Act, 1956 as it is unable to pay the debts claimed by the appellants?

anchor.surface_text: section 43 3  c  of the Companies Act, 1956 as the companypany is unable to pay the following debts.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany was insolvent and it was just and equitable to wind up the companypany.

issues.text: Whether the substratum of the respondent company has gone justifying winding up?

anchor.surface_text: An allegation that the substratum of the companypany is gone is to be alleged and proved as a fact

issues.text: Whether the court should ascertain and consider the wishes of the creditors and shareholders under section 557 of the Companies Act, 1956 and refuse winding up if majority oppose?

anchor.surface_text: Under section 557 of the Company Act 1956 [...] in all matters relating to the winding up of the companypany the companyrt may ascertain the wishes of the creditors. The wishes of the shareholders are also companysidered though perhaps the companyrt may attach greater weight to the views of the creditors.

arguments.claim: If debt bona fide disputed with substantial defence, court will not wind up the company.

anchor.surface_text: Two rules are well settled. First if the debt is bona fide disputed and the defence is a substantial one, the companyrt will number wind up the companypany.

arguments.claim: Court considers defence in good faith and of substance, likely to succeed in law, with prima facie proof of facts.

anchor.surface_text: The principles on which the companyrt acts are first that the defence of the companypany is in good faith and one of substance, secondly, the defence is likely to succeed in point of law and thirdly the companypany adduces prima facie proof of the facts on which the defence depends.

arguments.claim: Court ascertains and considers wishes of creditors and shareholders under s.557, greater weight to creditors; may refuse if majority oppose for good reason.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 557 of the Company Act 1956 [...] in all matters relating to the winding up of the companypany the companyrt may ascertain the wishes of the creditors. The wishes of the shareholders are also companysidered though perhaps the companyrt may attach greater weight to the views of the creditors.

arguments.claim: Substratum gone must be alleged and proved; trading losses or asset sale do not destroy if reasonable future profit prospects.

anchor.surface_text: An allegation that the substratum of the companypany is gone is to be alleged and proved as a fact

arguments.claim: Company has not abandoned objects; intends export business with sale proceeds, supported by Nandkishore group.

anchor.surface_text: In determining whether or number the substratum of the companypany has gone, the objects of the companypany and the case of the companypany on that question will have to be looked into. In the present case the, companypany alleged that with the proceeds of sale the companypany in- tended to enter into some other profitable business.

holdings.text: If the debt is bona fide disputed and the defence is a substantial one, the court will not wind up the company.

anchor.surface_text: Two rules are well settled. First if the debt is bona fide disputed and the defence is a substantial one, the companyrt will number wind up the companypany.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court follows settled principles from precedents: defence in good faith, substantial, likely to succeed in law, with prima facie proof of facts.

holdings.text: The principles on which the court acts are first that the defence of the company is in good faith and one of substance, secondly, the defence is likely to succeed in point of law and thirdly the company adduces prima facie proof of the facts on which the defence depends.

anchor.surface_text: The principles on which the companyrt acts are first that the defence of the companypany is in good faith and one of substance, secondly, the defence is likely to succeed in point of law and thirdly the companypany adduces prima facie proof of the facts on which the defence depends.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Elaboration of test for bona fide substantial dispute applied to facts like lack of privity, limitation, no demand, books of account.

holdings.text: If there is opposition to the making of the winding up order by the creditors the court will consider their wishes and may decline to make the winding up order. Under section 557 of the Companies Act 1956 in all matters relating to the winding up of the company the court may ascertain the wishes of the creditors.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 557 of the Company Act 1956 [...] in all matters relating to the winding up of the companypany the companyrt may ascertain the wishes of the creditors. The wishes of the shareholders are also companysidered though perhaps the companyrt may attach greater weight to the views of the creditors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Majority creditors by value (Rs.7,50,000) and all shareholders oppose winding up for good reasons; court tests reasonableness.

holdings.text: The claims of the appellants are disputed in fact and in law. [...] On these facts and on the principles of law to which reference has been made the High Court was correct in refusing the order for winding up.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the claims of the appellants are disputed in fact and in law. The companypany has given prima facie evidence that the appellants are number entitled to any claim for erection work, because there was numbertransaction between the companypany and the appellants or those persons in whose names the appellants claimed the amounts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Company adduced prima facie proof: no privity, limitation bar, no demand, board resolutions, receipts; claims tainted by dishonesty.

holdings.text: It cannot in the facts and circumstances of the present case be held that the substratum of the company is gone. Nor can it be held [...] that the company is unable to meet the outstandings of any of its admitted creditors.

anchor.surface_text: An allegation that the substratum of the companypany is gone is to be alleged and proved as a fact [...] In the present case the, companypany alleged that with the proceeds of sale the companypany in- tended to enter into some other profitable business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Company has not abandoned objects; plans export business with sale proceeds; reasonable prospects despite losses; precedents followed.

holdings.text: The facts and circumstances of the present case indicate [improper] motive.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel on behalf of the companypany companytended that the appel- lants presented the petition out of improper motive. Improper motive can be spelt out where the position is presented to companyrce the companypany

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition timed post-resignation to block machinery sale; abuse of process even if insolvent, citing English precedent.

holdings.text: The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts. The companypany and the supporting creditors will get one hearing fee. The amount of Rs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of bona fide dispute, creditor wishes, substratum intact, improper motive justifies upholding refusal of winding up.

precedents.citation: Amalgamated COmmercial Traders P Ltd. v.A. K. Krishnaswami and Anr. 35 Company cases 456

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Amalgamated COmmercial Traders P Ltd. v.A. K. Krishnaswami and Anr. 1 dealt with a petition to wind up the companypany on the ground that the companypany was indebted to the petitioner there for a sum of Rs. 1,750 being the net dividend

precedents.case_name: Amalgamated Commercial Traders P Ltd v A K Krishnaswami
precedents.cited_proposition: non-payment of dividend was bona fide disputed by the company and not to hide inability to pay debts
precedents.cited_holding: the non-payment of dividend was bona fide disputed by the company. It was not a dispute to hide its inability to pay the debts

precedents.citation: London and Paris Banking Corporation 1874 L.R. 19 Eq. 444

anchor.surface_text: the companyrt has dismissed a petition for winding up where the creditor claimed a sum for goods sold to the companypany and the companypany companytended that numberprice had been agreed upon. and the sum demanded by the, creditor was unreasonable See London and Paris Banking Corporation 1

precedents.cited_proposition: court dismissed winding up petition where creditor claimed sum for goods sold but company contended no price agreed and sum unreasonable

precedents.citation: Re. Brighton Club and Norfold Hotel Co. Ltd. 1865 35 Beav. 204

anchor.surface_text: Again, a petition for winding up by a creditor who claimed payment of an agreed sum for work done for the companypany When the companypany companytended that the work had number been done properly was number allowed. See Re. Brighton Club and Norfold Hotel Co. Ltd. 2

precedents.case_name: Re Brighton Club and Norfold Hotel Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: winding up petition refused where creditor claimed payment for work but company contended work not properly done

anchor.surface_text: Where the debt is undisputed the companyrt will number act upon a defence that the companypany has the ability to pay the debt but the companypany chooses number to pay that particular debt See Re. A Company 94 S.J. 369

precedents.cited_proposition: where debt undisputed, court will not refuse winding up merely because company has ability to pay but chooses not to

anchor.surface_text: Where however there is numberdoubt that the companypany owes the creditor a debt entitling him to a winding up order but the exact amount of the debt is disputed the companyrt will make a winding up order without requiring the creditor to quantity the debt precisely See Re. Tweeds Garages Ltd. 3

precedents.cited_proposition: if no doubt debt owing but amount disputed, court makes winding up order without precise quantification

precedents.citation: Re. P. J. Macrae Ltd. 1961 1 A.E.R. 302

anchor.surface_text: The grounds furnished by the creditors opposing the winding up will have an. important bearing on the reasonableness of the case See Re. P. J. Macrae Ltd. 1

precedents.cited_proposition: court considers wishes of majority creditors opposing winding up, and may refuse order if reasonable grounds

precedents.citation: Re. Suburban Hotel Co. 1867 2 Ch. App. 737

anchor.surface_text: the mere fact that the companypany has suffered trading losses will number destroy its substratum unless there is numberreasonable prospect of it ever making a profit in the future, and the companyrt is reluctant to hold that it has numbersuch prospect. See Re. Suburban Hotel Co. 1

precedents.cited_proposition: trading losses do not destroy substratum unless no reasonable prospect of future profit

precedents.citation: Davis Co. v. Brunswick Australia Ltd. 1936 1 A.F.R. 299

anchor.surface_text: See Re. Suburban Hotel Co. 1 and Davis Co. v. Brunswick Australia Ltd. 2 The companypany alleged that out of the proceeds of sale of the machinery the companypany would have sufficient money for carrying on export business even if the companypany were to take into companysideration the amount of Rs 1,45,000 alleged to be due on account of rent.

precedents.case_name: Davis & Co v Brunswick Australia Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: trading losses do not destroy substratum unless no reasonable prospect of future profit

anchor.surface_text: In the recent English decision in Mann Anr. Goldstein Anr. 1 it was held that even though it appeared from the evidence that the companypany was insolvent, as the debts were substantially ,disputed the companyrt restrained the prosecution of the petition as an abuse of the process of the companyrt.

precedents.cited_proposition: even if company insolvent, if debts substantially disputed, court restrains petition as abuse of process
precedents.cited_holding: even though it appeared from the evidence that the company was insolvent, as the debts were substantially disputed the court restrained the prosecution of the petition as an abuse of the process of the court

anchor.surface_text: Two rules are well settled. First if the debt is bona fide disputed and the defence is a substantial one, the companyrt will number wind up the companypany.

The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs. The companypany and the supporting creditors will get one hearing fee. The amount of Rs.
